Recipes.Recipe:
PRODUCT RECIPE
Cook the pancake batter on the flattop with oil.
Use a 6 fl.oz ladle for portioning and 1 pancakes is a portion
To plate and finish, put the pancake on a plate and drizzle/zigzag with the mayo from squeeze bottle.
Sprinkle with shredded nori and green onion
1 pancake = 220g (double check this)

1 - Preheat tilt fryer to 375
2 - Saute all veg with garlic and ginger until tender
3 - Add pineapple and juice until slow simmer
4 - Add chili sauce and vinegar and continue to simmer
5 - Add both sugars and water and simmer for 30 minutes
6 - Add cornstarch slurry and whisk until thickened
7 - Let simmer for another 30 minutes
8 - Remove from heat
9 - Cool, label and refrigerate

PREP RECIPE
Prepare pickling liquid as per recipe
Add red onions.
Allow to pickle 24 hours if possible
Add to appropriate vessel, label, date and refrigerate

method:

Stirfry quickly in a very hot pan with oil: onions, celery and bell peppers
Chop parsley
Squeeze liquid from crab meat and check for shell fragments
Mix all ingredients together including the eggs, mayo and breadcrumbs
Shape into 2 oz (60g) cakes
Makes approximately 40 pieces

ALLERGENS: GLUTEN (HOISIN)
Prep:
- Assemble: Black Cardamom, Star Anise, Coriander Seed, Cinnamon, and Nutmeg. Toast spices until fragrant, and then create a Sachet D'Epices with it, using cheesecloth and cooking twine.
- Pick: Celery Leaves, and Cilantro leaves from Stems. Keep the Stems of the Cilantro and the Celery Leaves separately (together). The Celery Stalks will be used in the making of the stock; the Cilantro Leaves will be used as garnish when serving; the Cilantro Stems and Celery Leaves will be added to the final step of the stock as aromatics.
- Peel Daikon completely and cut into 2" round pieces. Do the same with the White Onions in this recipe. Grill both of these until blackened on both sides - essentially burnt. This is important to the process.
- Place these burnt Daikon and Onion pieces into a large hotel pan, and then add: Cabbage, Garlic, Ginger, and Celery Stalks. Steam for 30 minutes, allowing water to accumulate in the hotel pan throughout the process.
- Fill the Steam Kettle with the 50 L of water in this recipe. Turn on, and begin heating.
- When the steaming ingredients are done, add to the Steam Kettle. When this is done, bring the mixture to a boil, and add the Sachet D'Epices. At this point, add Soy Sauce, Tamarind Paste, Brown Sugar, and Rice Vinegar.
- This stock can be done overnight, but it is not necessary. It should reach a boil for an hour - at least - and then it should reduce to a simmer, and be left for at least 2 hours. During the simmering process, salt can be added to taste. 200 grams are listed in the recipe, but this is an approximation.
- When heat is reduced to a simmer, add Cilantro Stems and Celery Leaves, and turn heat off all together. Allow these to steap for half an hour at least, and give the mixture a good stir before straining.
Label / Date / Store Appropriately!

- Roast all Chilis at 400F - Place Each Chili on SEPARATE Oven Pan - Anchos will be done first... - Guajillos will be done around the same time... - Chipotle will need more time - roast until almost black...
- SEED ALL CHILIS ONCE THEY'VE COOLED DOWN! - Break them open and shake out the seeds. - Keep as much of the "flesh" as possible.
- IN THE VITAMIX: - Blitz the remaining "flesh" into a powder. - Add Oil, Sugar, Salt, and Lime Juice - Using Hand Blender / Immersion Blender to Mix
- Date / Label & Store!

Prep: - Soak Tomatillos in Warm water for half an hour - Brush through them with your hand to loosen "jackets". The more the better... - Take off all of the Tomatillos outer jackets
Pre-Oven: - Ready 2 Deep Hotel Pans for Ingredients - Half all Tomatillos to ready them for roasting - Cut Onions - Add Garlic Whole - Half Jalapenos and Serranos, Remove Stems - Set Aside All Remaining Ingredients - Oil and Salt Ingredients in Hotel Pans
Oven: - Roast for up to 30-40 minutes at 375For until caramelized - add water and cook for another 60-90 minutes - Stir Occasionally to circulate caramelized top! - Remove and Cool! - Cooling this is key to its colour. If remaining ingredients are added (namely cilantro) to a warm sauce before blending, the green will turn to brown.
Post-Cooling: - Add 6 of the 8 Bunches of the cilantro to the mixture, and blend with the Large Hand Blender / Immersion Blender. Take 3 Cups of the mixture, and add the remaining 2 bunches of cilantro to the Vitamix. Blend in the Vitamix until it is a uniform deep green mixture. Add to the remaining mixture. - Continuing with the Large Hand Blender / Immersion Blender, lime juice, and salt to taste.

- PRE-SOAK Beans overnight! - 2 X 20L CAMBRO Containers - HALF of the Beans in Each - Filled with 12L of Water Each
- Drain Beans from their hydration liquid. Your cooking water should be different from your soaking water.
- Using the Small Steam Kettle, Cook Beans slowly in 20 extra liters of water. They should be good to start at 250F.
- Cook the beans until they are soft, but not decomposing. During the cooking process it is important to skim off the foamy protein that will accumulate at the surface of the cooking beans' water - this, if unchecked, will lead to a poor bitter taste and a lesser shelf life for the beans themselves.
- While the beans are cooking, saute your onions in Canola Oil, until dark brown. Caramelize them as far as they will go, and then add Cumin and Garlic. Saute Cumin and Garlic for 5 minutes, and then take off heat.
- Turn off Steam Kettle when the beans are cooked, and let beans sit. Take 4L of the cooking water, and set aside.
- Drain beans, and then transfer them into a neutral container greater than 40L in volume. Get the large Hand Blender / Immersion Blender.
- Add the Onion mixture with the Garlic and Cumin, as well as half of the Salt, and half of the Brown Sugar. The remaining halves - set aside, and use to SEASON TO TASTE.
- With the Hand Blender / Immersion Blender, blend about 4L of the bean mixture into a puree - and then add back into the rest of the beans, and mix. Add reserve liquid from the cooking, until you get - not a soup - beans with a puree of more beans.
- Cool, Label/Date, and Store.

Prep:
- Dissolve Tomato Paste in the "Water For Recipes" used to cook the Rice in the Combi Oven (this will result in the Rice turning Red.)
- Once Rice is out of the oven, add all ingredients - Oil, Rice Spice - into the rice in a big mixing bowl, and mix until incorporated.
- When adding the Rice Spice - you are SEASONING TO TASTE. The Rice Spice mixture has salt in it. Mix it in until you can taste the salt, and the spice will be perfect!

PREP RECIPE
Heat the oil.
Cook the onions about 10 minutes.
Add the beef cubes, and cook, stirring frequently until the meat is no longer pink on the outside, about 10 minutes.
Stir in the vindaloo paste, tomatoes, and squash and cook for 5 minutes.
Pour in the water, and bring to a simmer.
Cover and reduce heat to medium-low; cook until the beef is tender, about 40 minutes.
Season to taste and garnish with cilantro to serve.

Use a blender if you like, it is easier. A whisk will work too.
***Please make sure to mix tahini before you use it as it settles and separates.

Allergens: Method:
1. Open 2.8L cans of pineapple.
2. Drain Liquid - Reserve
3. In the convection oven - at 400F - roast the drained pineapple for 10 Minutes, or until darkening and caramelizing on the outside.
4. Remove from oven, and let sit until they've reached room temperature...
*IN THE MEANTIME*
5. Set up the ROBOT COUPE
*THEN*
6. In batches (4-5), begin pulsing the lime juice, some of the drained pineapple juice from the cans(use as needed to gain the right concistensy wont need it all) salt & coriander - letting the processor do its job until the mixture is at a chunky puree!
-Cool, store, label and rotate this item with older product correctly and diligently.

- Once your Pork Butts are ready to prepare, score their tops (THE FATTY PART) with cross-hashed cuts up to 1CM deep, OK?!
- At this point, rub the Pork "Butts" with the dry spices (Cumin, Cinnamon, Cayenne +), salt, and achiote. The Achiote paste can also be mixed into a little bit of orange juice or pineapple juice to make it easier to rub in.
- In Deep Hotel Pans, place all of the butts in there with the Onions, Garlic, and wet ingredients (Water, Pineapple Juice, Orange Juice) - THEN - pre-heat your oven to 275-300 Degrees (F).
The level of the wet ingredients should come halfway up pork, add more water if need be. Wrap with foi
Cook for 4.5-7 hours. At 4 hours, you can check to see how this process is going.
Label/Date/Store!

- Using the Vitamix, take 1 can of Chipotle Peppers (In Adobo) and blitz them into a fine puree with this recipe's Lime Juice.
- Fold into Sour Cream and add Salt.
Label/Date/Store!

ALLERGENS: MUSTARD
Prep:
1. Clean and cut Potatoes into large uniform shapes and sizes. Each Potato may yield 6 pieces, if cut properly - about the same style as Homestyle Potatoes. Steam these in the combi oven until soft but not crumbling apart - use the steam setting: check after 30 minutes.
2. Cut the Cauliflower into florets, and deep fry until golden brown - then set aside. Rough Chop Onions, and set aside your Ginger and Garlic. While you're doing this, set aside your spices - to be used at the beginning of the cooking process. Also, set aside your 4 litres of Water (though, it may not be necessary).
5. In the Tilt Skillet, starting with Canola Oil - start to saute your onions (towards caramelized). Then, throw in your spices, and saute them as well - before adding your Garlic and Ginger.
6. As soon as you add your Garlic and Ginger, you're going to want to deglaze the Tilt Skillet by adding up to 3 litres of the water you set aside. At this point you can add your Turmeric, Garam Masala, Mustard, and canned Tomatoes.
7. Let simmer for a few minutes before adding the fried Cauliflower, and Potatoes. Turn up the heat on the skillet at this point, and scrape the bottom of the skillet with the mixing paddle to accumulate caramelized sugars therein that will burn if left unincorporated. Use the remaining water in this recipe, or more, if need be - keep it moving! You're near the end here.
8. Turn the temperature down on the Tilt Skillet. Rough Chop the Cilantro and Mint. Cut the Serrano Peppers thinly on a mandoline, and then throw all of these ingredients into the mixture.
9. Season to taste at this point - the salt in this recipe is roughly 1.2% of recipe weight. You may find that you need more.
10. Finish with lime juice before serving. This could change depending on how you're doing your batches - but the finished product should be given acidity with lime juice prior to serving regardless of how this dish interacts with the Hot Holds.
Any questions - Ask Chef!

ALLERGENS: SESAME, SOY
Prep:
- In a Vitamix, puree the Black Garlic, Garlic. Lime Juice and Water together until no small pieces of Black Garlic remain - until the mixture is 100% uniform.
- Add Soy and remaining ingredients, and - while the Vitamix is running on a lower setting (than necessary to puree the Black Garlic) - ease in the Xanthan Gum until the mixture thickens to a sauce-like viscousity.
Label / Date / Store Appropriately!

PREP RECIPE
Combine and allow the pickle juice to pickle the cabbage.

combine everything and mix

SEQUENCE!
1. Tortilla! 2. Rice 3. Beans 4. Black Chili Mayo 5. Chicken 6. Pico De Gallo 7. Serrano Peppers 8. Cabbage Mix
Roll!
Note: SEQUENCE IS IMPORTANT!
As a general rule, it is best to put sauces on the Burrito right after the Rice & Beans stage. If you put the sauces on last, or at the top (facing the customer) of the Burrito - it will be a mess when you go to roll it. It's a good technique to put Cabbage, Cheese, or Arugula at the top of the Burrito (facing the customer) before rolling it, as this will keep your hands clean, and help you save on glove waste!

PREP RECIPE
Chop down shallots and galangal as required.
Add all ingredients to a large bucket and add just enough water to get it to mix.
Use the large hand blender to puree to a smooth paste.
Reserve for use in the curry recipe.

PREP RECIPE
Saute the massaman curry paste until cooked out.
Add onions, red peppers, and brown sugar. Cook out onions.
Add coconut milk, and turn heat down. Add lime leaves. Simmer this mixture for 20-30 minutes on low heat. Cover for best results.
Add potatoes and salt.
Let simmer now, adding water if need be, until potatoes are cooked out.
Once potatoes are cooked out, take off heat,mix in lime juice to finish and conduct final seasoning assesment and adjustment.

PREP RECIPE
Combine in hotel pans and slow cook at 350F in the oven until beef is tender. 2-3 hours
Strain off some of the stock to make service more managable, reserving the stock for another purpose.

ALLERGENS: WHEAT, GLUTEN
Prep:
- Take the Coriander Seeds, Cumin Seeds, Ajwain Seeds, Black Pepper and Garam Masala - and toast, then grind in the Vitamix into a fine powder. The toasting, as mentioned in other recipes, is key to developing flavour and aroma.
- Amchur Powder is not a spice, but a powder made of green mango. It should not be toasted. Opinions differ on this, but - for this recipe, do not toast this ingredient.
- Normally this recipe would be made into a paste with lemon juice and a small amount of water. We use this as a more dry rub, in combination with alread-wet ingredients like potatoes that have been boiled and chickpeas that sit in "aqua fava" (literally: bean water).
- If this spice mix is low, talk to a Chef about it. Some of these ingredients come from a specialty provider with an indented delivery schedule - and will need to be ordered several days in advance in order to allow for proper prep time.
Any questions - Ask Chef!

ALLERGENS: N/A
Prep:
- Basically, this is a bound puree of Cilantro and Mint. All of the other ingredients in this recipe are more there for context.
- Place all ingredients (and, it's OK to use ground coriander in this recipe, even without toasting it)(don't worry, other flavours in this recipe will pick up where it otherwise would have done its thing) into a Vitamix. Keep Xanthan Gum aside.
- Start the Vitamix, and slowly raise the speed setting until you're working with a fine puree of all of the aforementioned ingredients. On "High" (the button to the left of the speed setting nob), remove the plunger from the pitcher base, and add the Xanthan Gum while the mixture is moving.
- Keeping in mind while you're doing this that the base of the Vitamix will heat up, causing your greens inside this puree to become bitter and discolour. Therefore, it's best if this it done quickly - but do not sacrifice quality for haste!
- You should know, with this recipe, and all recipes requiring a binder like Xanthan Gum, how a thickener is doing in its job. To test this mixture, turn the Vitamix off, and dip the plunger into the mixture, then raise it to see how slowly it falls off the plunger. It should fall slowly. If it doesn't, add more Xanthan Gum binder, and continue. The idea is that this will become a paste that will get things dipped into it.
- Don't worry - if you thicken it too much, you can always go backwards and let it out again, easily. This is not like over-cooking a steak. That said, know what you're looking for, and do it.
- Label / Date / Store Appropriately...
Any questions - Ask Chef!

ALLERGENS: N/A
Prep:
- Basically, this is a bound gel of sweetened Tamarind Paste. 1 Jar is 300g, so the recipe is built around that.
- Fresh Tamarind, which isn't very widely available here in North America, is not very tart at all like Tamarind Paste. Citric Acid, other additives, and industrial processes force it to be this way - so it needs to be let out and sweetened. Allspice in this recipe is used to mask some of the bendinf that this ingredient must go through.
- Place all ingredients into a Vitamix. Keep Xanthan Gum aside.
- Start the Vitamix, and slowly raise the speed setting until you're working with a fine mixture of all of the aforementioned ingredients. On "High" (the button to the left of the speed setting nob), remove the plunger from the pitcher base, and add the Xanthan Gum while the mixture is moving.
- You should know, with this recipe, and all recipes requiring a binder like Xanthan Gum, how a thickener is doing in its job. To test this mixture, turn the Vitamix off, and dip the plunger into the mixture, then raise it to see how slowly it falls off the plunger. It should fall slowly. If it doesn't, add more Xanthan Gum binder, and continue. The idea is that this will become like a paste that will get things dipped into it.
- Don't worry - if you thicken it too much, you can always go backwards and let it out again, easily. This is not like over-cooking a steak. That said, know what you're looking for, and do it.
- Label / Date / Store Appropriately...
Any questions - Ask Chef!

ALLERGENS: N/A
Prep:
- THIS RECIPE IS A TOUGH ONE; CRISPY SHALLOTS ARE AN ART FORM. PLEASE FOLLOW INSTRUCTIONS CAREFULLY, AND GET CHEF TO DO THIS WITH YOU ONCE BEFORE TRYING IT ON YOUR OWN.
- Mandoline Shallots into thin rings - Approx. 2mm.
- Created a Salt/Water Brine at 10% salt (100g Salt: 1000ml Water). Soak mandolined Shallots in Brine for 10 minutes. Rinse once with clean water, and let rest for 20 minutes.
- At 325-350F, fry Shallots until golden. Shallots will continue cooking once you take them out - and set them on a tray lined with paper towel. IMPORTANT: as soon as you take the Shallots out of the fryer, and onto their blotting surface of paper towel, you will need to move them around so that they don't clump up and form balls or nests (which, once dried, will not come apart easy). THIS IS VERY IMPORTANT TO GETTING A GOOD PRODUCT.
- Any questions (especially with this recipe, as the yield is low), PLEASE ASK CHEF!

SEQUENCE:
1. Tortilla 2. Rice 3. Beans 4. Sriracha Sour Cream 5. Pulled Pork 6. Pineapple "Sauce" 7. Cabbage Mix 8. Crispy Shallots
Roll!
Note: as a general rule, it is best to put sauces on the Burrito right after the rice & beans stage. If you put the sauces on last, or at the top (facing the customer) of the burrito - it will be a mess when you go to roll it. It's a good technuique to put the cabbage, cheese, or arugula at the top of the burrito (facing the customer) before rolling it, as this will keep your hands clean, and help you save on glove waste.
Combine and mix

Make a marinade from the ingredients and rub steak.
Grill or otherwise cook steak to complete the recipe.

- Drain Cannelini Beans. The Yield on these beans has been calculated in this recipe - roughly the loss of over a Kilogram in "Aqua Fava". A quick rinse is valued, but not entirely necessary.
- Half all Grape Tomatoes. You will notice in this recipe that 5 LBS is the measured amount require. This is because each box of Grape Tomatoes that comes in from Freshpoint is 10 LBS - meaning: use half of a box for this recipe. Easy enough?
- Small Dice Red Onions. Saute with Cumin and Cayenne, adding 1 Bag of Frozen Corn and Red Pepper to the mix along the way. Do not roast this Corn in the oven for any reason - its starches develop and it becomes tough texturally. Deglaze this mixture with Apple Cider Vinegar, and season.
- Pick Oregano. Don't bother picking the Cilantro, as some stem is fine in this recipe. Rough Chop both of these, and reserve to add into the rest of this recipe.
- Label / Date / Store Appropriately...
NOTE: This recipe will last if properly refrigerated for up to 5 days. This is a large batch for this item, since it's new to the menu and may not sell well depending on diner preferences. Do not make more than this until it's proven that it will move. Waste not want not!

PREP RECIPE
Combine and boil to dissolve sugar and bring flavours out of spices and seasonings.
Pour over ingredient to be pickled and allow time to work its magic.

1 PTN = 90 g
NOTES: This is a recipe where tasting is very important, as well as an understanding of what a product is or how it's supposed to taste. Each Item in this recipe has a specific process associated with it - when combined, it can be delicious.
Also, RE: ALLERGENS: it's important to know that there is no bread in this recipe. Only one item contains Wheat Fiber as an additive that makes it easier to use in a culinary setting.
Order Method:
1. Potatoes (>1" Cubes / Steamed) 2. Chickpeas (Pre-Cooked / Drained, Rinsed) 3. Tomatoes (Small Dice) 4. Cucumbers (Small Dice) 5. Red Onions (Fine Dice) 6. Chaat Spice (TOSS ALL AFOREMENTIONED ITEMS) 7. Salt (INCORPORATE WHEN TOSSING OTHERS)
8. Tamarind Chutney, Mint / Cilantro Chutney & Yogurt 9. Mint (Picked) & Cilantro (Rough Chop w/ Mint) 10. "Sev" (Dried Chickpea Noodle Snack)
Prep:
- Process the Potatoes in the Combi Oven on its Steam setting. Take Chickpeas out of can(s) (in appropriate weights).
- Cut all Vegetable ingredients. This step, and the one before it with the Potatoes and Chickpeas can be done in advance. Both can be combined, but kept separate for service (Potatoes and Chickpeas, then Tomatos, Red Onions and Cucumbers). Mint and Cilantro should be processed separately, but can be combined for service.
- Chutneys and Yogurt will be processed in advance, and the bottled for service. Chat spice should be kept separate.
- Combine all, and TASTE!

ALLERGENS: MUSTARD, NON-HALAL (WINE IN THE MUSTARD).
Notes:
This is not a traditional Vindaloo, but no one really has a good idea of what Vindaloo is - really. Many British adopters of Indian cuisine, when it hit England, didn't know that they were eating a Vindaloo made by predominantly Sri Lankan immigrants that the British just assumed were Indian. These immigrants from Sri Lanka, who ended up being lumped into British society as essentially a sub-brand of Indian people, were largely different from the majority of East Indians because they mostly Muslim.
The dish was originally a cultural mash-up that was born out of Portuguese colonial influence in Goa. It was originally made with Pork and Wine Vinegar -but, since Sri Lankans are mostly Muslim, the dish became wine-less and pork-less (Lamb, Goat, and Beef stepped in to create what most now understand as what the dish should be), and was hence reborn under the name Vindaloo in 1950's/60's Britain as what people assume it to be today. Like many Indian dishes, it has a rich history - just lesser known, in its essential details, than others. This recipe for the base paste is somewhere between its original ethos, and its modern twists.
Prep:
- THE NIGHT BEFORE: Open up the can of Roasted Red Peppers. Add Chili Flakes, and Red Wine Vinegar. Soak overnight. You can also put together your spices the day before - this would be wise, no?
- THE DAY OF: Process Onions however you'd like. This mix will be puree'd once it's cooked out.
- Begin to cook out Onions. Caramelization is fine - high heat is best. Toast Spices. Add Garlic and Ginger - cook those out. Add Dijon Mustard, and cook out slightly. Then! Add Water, and let simmer. Add soaked mixture of Roasted Red Peppers, Chilis, and Vinegar, from th previous day.
- Simmer for 30-45 minutes, and then puree with an Immersion Blender until it becomes a fine paste.
- Label / Date / Store Appropriately...
***This recipe can be made in advance in large batches, and then vac-packed and frozen for future use.
Any questions? - Ask Chef...

ALLERGENS: MILK (PANEER)
Notes:
This recipe should be as green as possible - meaning: stewing the green elements of this recipe too far will kill the flavour and visual appeal of the recipe. The idea of this recipe is to have a flavourful earthy base to balance out the fats present in the Paneer (which is to be added last).
Prep:
- Cut the root ends off of the Green Onions, and then grill them until coloured. Cool, and then chop up in pieces that are no less than 3 inches long.
- Rough Chop Onions, and begin cooking them out immediately. Throw in Spices, Garlic, and Ginger. Deglaze with water. Season and simmer for 5-10 minutes.
- Cut Paneer into mouthful-sized cubes - nothing too big. It will cut like Tofu, but it will also flake off, as it does not have gypsum as a binder, and soy proteins are different from milk fat proteins.
- Add HALF of the Spinach in the recipe, and cover for 5 minutes. You want the Spinach to be cooked out, but not to the point of bitterness. At this point, the recipe is very close to being taken off heat.
- Add the Cilantro in this recipe. Then, using an Immersion Blender, puree the Spinach and its juices into a sauce. This does not have to be a uniform puree as it would come out of a Vitamix - a little bit of texture is OK. Check for seasoning.
- Add Chopped Green Onions (grilled), Paneer, the other half of the Spinach, and the Cilantro - season again to taste using the salt in this recipe. Turn off heat.
- Add Yogurt before moving this recipe into Hotel Pans for serving.
Any questions? - Ask Chef...

Allergens: wheat, gluten, milk
Icons:
Method:
place 1 portion of garlic bread on a plate
serve

1. Assemble all the ingredients. 2. Saute the onions and pureed lemon grass until translucent, add ginger and garlic and cook out for another 5 minutes. Add sugar and cook for another 5 minutes. 3. Add Green Curry Paste and cook out for another 5 minutes to develop flavour. 4. Add coconut milk, bring to a simmer, add lime leaves and season. 5. Thicken with slury, thicken so that sauce coats the back of a spoon and sticks. 6. Add lime juice just before you take it off the heat. 7. Throw in the thai basil and cilantro and blend in the sauce to give it it's green color.******
****** If you are making the sauce for the next day, DO NOT add the cilantro/thai basil as it will go brown and discolor.
Label, date, refrigerate.

PREP RECIPE
Soak the black beans.
Saute your onions unitl softened, add the garlic and ginger. Saute some more, and mix in the brown sugar to combine and then deglaze when you're ready with soy sauce.
Simmer, and the add water. Strain the black beans, and then add them to the simmering mixture, and simmer further until the black beans are soft.
Prepare your potato starch into a slurry with 500ml of water, and incorporate.

Combine rice in a 1:1 water ratio.

Stir the vinegar/mirin mixture into the rice to complete the seasoning.

Preps used in this Product recipe: Seafood Pancake.
Allergens: (To be filled out by nutrition) Method:
1. Thaw out seafood (apropriately) once fully thawed it is imparative to this recipe that all seafood is well drained a squeezed (gently) of exess water or soggy pancakes will happen! cheesecloth is great for this aplication.
2. Chope tha calamari into a small dice, Chop the kimchi into a manageable size.
3. Combine veg and processed (dry) seafood together
4. Add the clams with necter to the mix (clam necter is used in place of some of the water that would normally take place in a pancake batter)
5. Add the flour and pancake mix, incorporate enough water to combine and mix untill everything is thuroughly mixed and the proper batter consistancy is achieved
6. Cook a test pancake and check for seasoning, texture and balance. Adjust seasoning as needed.
7. Use 6 fl oz ladle for portioning. 1 pancake sholud weigh 220g (double check to see that it does, adjust portioning as needed) ladle should be a level scoop not rounded.

1. Add rice to hotel pan using a small lid, prop the hotel pan up on an angle in sink. Rinse rice in cold water agitating rice by hand and letting water drain off naturally. Rinse until water runs clear

cube tofu and toss through seasoned cornstarch.
